ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Intense. I can see how transport is useful in many engineering fields, but be prepared to devote a significant amount of time to this class - it can consume your semester.

This class sucks, but youre majoring in chemical engineering, so youre probably a masochist anyway. Sorry, that was mean, and your year is going to be rough enough without my snark. Keep chugging along, youre almost done. Almost...Professor Osuji is a great guy who genuinely cares about his students, but he doesnt quite understand that not everyone is as brilliant as he is. During lecture you should definitely stop him as often as you can to ask questions. I promise you no one else in the class will have any idea whats going on either, and the more you force him to stop or slow down and actually explain things, the better for everyone. Start the problem sets early, read the book since its exactly what he puts up on the board, and become an expert with MatLab as soon as possible, because even though its not a prerequisite, it really should be since Osuji expects you to be able to use it in just about every problem set. Lastly, if youre lucky enough to still be a freshman or sophomore looking into the classes you would have to take as a chem-e major, do yourself a favor and switch to something else if youre at all unsure that this is what you want to do. I may just be a jaded junior, but when over 3/4 of the people in the major regret choosing it, I get the feeling its probably not just me being whiny.

If you are looking at this class, you will probably have to take it anyways. Depending on who teaches the class, it can definitely be an intense class material-wise. Be prepared to work together with classmates getting the problem set done, and spending chunks of time studying to learn the material. You will be okay at the end though, good luck!
Heat transfer, mass transfer, and momentum transfer, and how they relate.

This is a requirement for the Chemical Engineering major, but you do get a lot our of the course and Professor Osuji goes through the material very thoroughly. However, this does require a lot of work and you will go through several lectures not understanding the material until you finally get it. Overall a very good class and you come out of it knowing core material of the chemical engineering major.
Only take if you're chemE. This is a very difficult course. Problem sets took a long time.
